Award.AwardTitle: Provision of Log Data Reduction and Database Services for Scientific Ocean Drilling
Award.AbstractNarration:
Provision of Log Data Reduction and Database Services for Scientific Ocean Drilling
The results and discoveries of scientific ocean drilling have broad relevance to a wide range of societal, educational, and public interests. One of the most important aspects of scientific ocean drilling is storing and making accessible well log data obtained during expeditions. The Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory (LDEO) has been involved in scientific ocean drilling with the NSF from the Ocean Drilling Program (ODP) through the current International Ocean Discovery Program (IODP). To date, more than 570 scientific drilling holes have been uploaded into the database, LogDB, including data for more than 33 km of drilled intervals, with more than 37,000 website visits for 2013 for data download. For the proposed work, LDEO will continue to provide scientists with quality-controlled well log data sets from future scientific expeditions and will also maintain historic well log data access. In addition, LDEO will collaborate with key database groups to enable LogDB and its associated scientific product to be broadly disseminated. This will broaden the use and impact of scientific ocean drilling data by connecting LogDB to other NSF-supported databases and facilities, increasing the accessibility of IODP log data to the broader scientific community.

Technical Description: The goals of this proposal are to provide scientists with quality-controlled well log data sets from future scientific expeditions and to maintain historic log data access. To accomplish this, log data will be transferred from the U.S. drillship, JOIDES Resolution, to shore for data reduction and QA/QC, with the resulting standard and image files transferred back to the ship for use during each expedition. At the end of each cruise, this dataset will be uploaded to the database, LogDB, for post-cruise, password-protected access for specific the scientific community. LDEO will continue to maintain LogDB, which provides a web-enabled database to safely store, search, and retrieve log data collected by DSDP, ODP, and IODP. LogDB has four components: secure storage of original and reduced log data files in a secure file system; a relational database containing log metadata for indexing and data queries; a web interface providing data search and retrieval, as well as access to documentation on data reduction and QA/QC steps; and a set of ReST-based web services, which provide an interface for third party data tools to interact directly with the database. The LDEO Borehole Research Group (BRG) will collaborate with logging operation groups in Europe and Japan to insure that log data collected and distributed by IODP are consistent across all platforms. In this effort, BRG will provide high quality log data access in as seamless a manner as possible for scientists onboard the JOIDES Resolution and to the international community. LDEO procedures have been designed to be operationally efficient and cost effective for the U.S. ship operator, Texas A&M University (TAMU), and to enhance LogDB user experiences with state-of-the-art database technology.

Institution.Name: Columbia University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project:  Provision of log data reduction and database services for scientific ocean drilling

The Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory (LDEO) has been involved with log data archiving and distribution since the mid-1990s, when LDEO pioneered the online distribution of Scientific Ocean Drilling (DSDP/ODP/IODP) data with the development of a log database (LogDB). Since that time, LogDB has increased in the volume and variety of data available by including log data acquired in programs other than scientific ocean drilling. LogDB has also been enhanced with developments in database technologies that allow for automated data query and retrieval. In this project, LDEO has worked closely with Schlumberger and shipboard personnel to refine the efficient flow of data and data quality control – from acquisition to distribution ­– in order to provide shipboard and shore-based scientists with the best final data products possible. LDEO has also collaborated with the European and Japanese scientific ocean drilling operators in order to insure that scientific ocean drilling data collected and distributed is consistent across all platforms to the extent possible.

To date, log data from 632 holes from the DSDP/ODP/IODP programs has been uploaded into LogDB, corresponding to almost 300 km of drilled intervals. Over the past 3 years, LDEO has performed data reduction and QA/QC for 22 new holes, corresponding to over 13 km of drilled intervals. In addition, LDEO has performed QA/QC on processed log data from 9 holes drilled by the Japanese scientific ocean drilling operator and 9 holes drilled by the European scientific ocean drilling operator. LDEO also provided logging expertise to scientists who have requested technical assistance when using well log data in their research.

LogDB outcomes have been disseminated to the scientific community through a web interface and web services:

Web Interface. LogDB web pages provide easy access to the log data and meta-databases. Data searches can be conducted by operational information (Program, Year, Leg/Exp, Hole), by geographic area (keyword or map selection), by measurement, by tool, or through a combination of these identifiers. Results are delivered as a summary list of holes meeting particular search criteria. Links also provide a means to drill down by hole to retrieve a summary of all files meeting the search parameters and provide a path to download files as a batch. Links to documentation about the field data collection, data reduction and processing, and QA/QC are also available.

Web Services Web services allow for data management and visualization tools and an interface for automated data query and retrieval from LogDB. Three types of services are currently available: (1) a catalog search (ReST/POX-type), (2) an OGSWeb Feature Service (WFS), and (3) a Measurement Dictionary (W3C SKOS). Together, these services allow third party software tools to harvest metadata, to directly query LogDB for data, to obtain geographic information about logged holes, and to generate lists of available measurements within LogDB. The uniform quality of these data is assured by the consistent application of QA/QC steps. In summary, the reach and impact of LogDB is amplified through these web services, providing tool developers with a well-defined interface to the archive of this comprehensive scientific log database.


Last Modified: 08/14/2017
Modified by: David S Goldberg
